text: Hiring manager perspective - I've hired many agency folks into software companies. Some of the reasons: Fast-paced. Deadline oriented. Not precious about your work and good at receiving and implementing feedback. Wider variety of projects and experience. Creative.

elements.text: Hiring manager perspective - I've hired many agency folks into software companies. Some of the reasons: Fast-paced. Deadline oriented. Not precious about your work and good at receiving and implementing feedback. Wider variety of projects and experience. Creative.

text:
Spent four years at an agency before going in-house:

• pitched (truthfully) that i was interested in in-house work because agency work sometimes keeps you at arms length/forces you to work toward vanity metrics.
• built and executed on lots of different strategies constantly. in-house, you might have 1-4 strategy sessions a year; agency life, you're doing it monthly (sometimes more often if you're helping out a colleague). that's a lot more exposure for different ways to do it, what works/doesn't, etc.
• lots of time talking with, listening to, reporting to c-suite people. agency life is great prep for working with c-suite people and, at a big company, framing your ideas to get them accepted.
• biggest reason i chose to work where i do now: the company was built (by the founder) on content, so there were no concerns about buy-in. i would be more worried going in-house at a company that was cruising along and decided---just recently---to add content on top of other marketing efforts. content is expensive, takes time to pay off, and has limited potential for attribution. those are terrible characteristics if you don't have top-to-bottom buy-in.
